WorkItem.Description:
DatePicker lets user to enter time and correctly parses it and stores in its SelectedDate property, but subsequently clears the text presentation to Date-only.
 
To reproduce:
 
        <UniformGrid>
            <TextBox
                Text="{Binding SelectedDate, ElementName=pick, UpdateSourceTrigger=PropertyChanged}"
                VerticalAlignment="Center" HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" Margin="8"/>
            <WpfToolkit:DatePicker x:Name="pick"
                VerticalAlignment="Center" HorizontalAlignment="Stretch" Margin="8"/>
        </UniformGrid>
 
Click on DatePicker's textbox, type in 01/01/2009 10:30. Press Tab. The bound textbox on the right shows the correct DateTime value with time.
 
 
 
What is wrong:
 
The data is expected to survive roundtrip from text to DateTime presentation, but it does not.
 
 
Proposed solution:
 
Detect whether SelectedDate has non-zero time and format it with time in that case.
Special handling also required when user chooses the date using mouse. In that case if before mouseclick SelectedDate had a non-zero time, the value after selection should accept the same TimeOfDay instead of going to 12:00 as of now.
WorkItem.Summary: DatePicker does not fully support TIME part of DateTime

Comments.Message: This is by design.  The DatePicker is only designed to handle dates, not times, and all of the behavior you describe (changing the time to 12:00 for example) is by design.  If you need the control to handle times, you'll need to subclass it or modify the source to be a DateTimePicker.
